content: The "Grand River Band of Ottawa Indians of Michigan Referral Act" includes sections on short title, table of contents, definitions, referral to the Secretary, membership, jurisdiction, land, and definitions. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as Band, Tribe, Date of recognition, Indian tribe, and Secretary. The purpose of Title I is to expedite the review of the Band's petition for recognition as a Federal Indian tribe. This is to ensure a timely and just determination under the rules governing the recognition of new Indian tribes. Additionally, a report is required under Section 102. The Secretary must review the Band's petition and report to Congress by August 31, 2005, determining if the majority are descendants of signatories of specific treaties. The Band's history is linked to Indian tribes descended from signatories of specific treaties, including the Ottawa and Chippewa nations. The Grand Traverse Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Chippewa Indians, Bay Mills Band of Chippewa Indians, Little Traverse Bay Band of Odawa Indians, and Little River Band of Ottawa Indians reside in the ancestral homeland in Michigan. The Band filed for tribal government reorganization in 1935 under the Indian Reorganization Act. The Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians sought reorganization under the Indian Reorganization Act but was denied due to lack of Federal appropriations. They maintained political and social existence through the Northern Michigan Ottawa Association, successfully pursuing a land claim. The Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians have had continuous dealings with government officials since 1836. They were included in the Michigan Indian Land Claims Settlement Act and needed to submit a petition by December 15, 2000, to qualify for land claim funds. The Secretary holds funds in trust for the Band pending recognition. The Secretary must consult with elected leaders of the Band, anthropologists, ethno-historians, and genealogists associated with the Band. The Secretary must consult with elected leaders, anthropologists, ethno-historians, and genealogists associated with the Band. If the Band satisfies all conditions, a positive report will be submitted to Congress by August 31, 2005. If any condition is not met, a negative report will be submitted by the same date. If the Secretary fails to submit a report by November 30, 2005, certain actions will be taken. The Secretary must recognize the Band as an Indian tribe by November 30, 2005, and title II will apply to the Band. SEC. 103. ACTION BY CONGRESS. If Congress acts on the Secretary's report within 60 days, positive reports lead to Band recognition as an Indian tribe, while negative reports return the Band's petition for further review. If Congress fails to act within 60 days on the Secretary's report, positive reports lead to Band recognition as an Indian tribe, while negative reports return the Band's petition for further review. The Band's petition will be added to the Office of Federal Acknowledgment list, and they will have the opportunity to prove their status as an Indian tribe. SEC. 201. The Secretary must recognize the Tribe by November 30, 2005, and publish notice in the Federal Register. SEC. 202. Membership. The Tribe must provide a list of current members within 120 days of recognition. Within 18 months, they must submit a membership roll of individuals eligible for membership, with qualifications determined by the Tribe in consultation with the Secretary. The Secretary will publish notice of the membership roll in the Federal Register. The Tribe must maintain the membership roll, which will be published in the Federal Register. The Tribe must maintain the membership roll, published in the Federal Register, as per SEC. 203 regarding Federal services and benefits. The Tribe and its members are eligible for Federal services and benefits as Indians regardless of reservation existence or residence location. The Tribe's jurisdiction extends to designated land and water for delivering Federal services to enrolled members. The Tribe's jurisdiction is consistent with Federal law, regardless of the existence of a treaty providing for their rights. SEC. 204. RIGHTS OF THE TRIBE. Any abrogated or diminished rights of the Tribe or its members before recognition are reaffirmed. This Act does not diminish existing rights or legal claims of the Tribe. It also does not affect future applications for placing land into trust. The Act reaffirms any abrogated or diminished rights of the Tribe or its members before recognition. It does not diminish existing rights or legal claims of the Tribe and does not affect future applications for placing land into trust or gaming activities. SEC. 205. TRIBAL FUNDS. Any funds set aside by the Secretary for use by the Tribe shall be made available to the Tribe. SEC. 206. JURISDICTION OF TRUST LAND. The Tribe shall have jurisdiction over all land taken into trust by the Secretary for the benefit of the Tribe, to the maximum extent allowed by law, including jurisdiction over members residing in the service area as defined by the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978.
